--- title: "Global Surface Temperature" subtitle: "Proposal" format: html editor: visual --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Dataset ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} global_temps <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-07-11/global_temps.csv') nh_temps <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-07-11/nh_temps.csv') sh_temps <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-07-11/sh_temps.csv') zonann_temps <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2023/2023-07-11/zonann_temps.csv') ``` ::: **Introduction**: The dataset is provided by NASA by combining land-surface, sea surface, air temperature anomalies. The values in the dataset are deviations from the corresponding 1951-1980 means, indicating how much warmer or colder it is than normal for a particular place and time, and the normal means the average over the 30-year period 1951-1980 for that place and time of year. More precisely, the base 1951-1980 mean is subtracted from the absolute temperature to get the anomaly. A brief description of the datasets is as below: ::: {.cell} ::: **global_temps.csv**: provides temperature anomalies of each month for every year. Seasonal and yearly anomaly averages are included as a convenience. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

This includes data at the global and hemispheric levels, as well as 11 unique latitudinal ranges between the Northern and Southern poles. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

64S-44S double 64S-44S lattitude
90S-64S double 90S-64S lattitude
````` ::: ::: ## Why this Dataset? **Analyzing climate datasets**: These datasets can help us understand past and present climate trends, and potentially predict future patterns. **Comprehensive view**: The datasets provide a comprehensive view of temperature changes from different perspectives - global, Northern Hemisphere, Southern Hemisphere, and zonal annual temperatures. **Impact on businesses**: The weather is changing significantly in some places, which might necessitate changes in how businesses operate in those areas. **Future planning for businesses**: By analyzing the temperature data, businesses can make plans for the future and decide what changes they might need to make to ensure their continued success. ## Questions 1. How can visualizations of the dataset illuminate trends in global and hemispheric temperature anomalies over time, aiding in the understanding of climate change's progression and its impacts on different regions of the Earth? 2. In what ways can comparing visualized data of seasonal temperature anomalies, as defined by meteorological seasons, provide insights into the shifting patterns of seasons and their potential effects on human livelihoods? ## Analysis plan **Referring to Question 1**: **Global Temperature Trends**: Plot global temperature anomalies over time using a line graph. Analyze the trend to understand long-term changes. csv file to be used: global_temps.csv **Zonal Temperature Comparisons**: Use facet graphs (example: bar, line, scatter) to compare temperature anomalies across different zones. Analyze mean deviations to understand variations within and between zones. csv file to be used: zonann_temps.csv **Referring to Question 2**: **Latitude-based Temperature Anomalies**: Create a heat map to visualize anomalies across latitude ranges and seasonal changes. Analyze spatial patterns to identify regions most affected by climate change. csv file to be used: zonann_temps.csv **Global Temperature Visualization**: Utilize ggmap to overlay temperature data onto a global map. Incorporate geographic features to contextualize temperature variations. csv file to be used: zonann_temps.csv, global_temps.csv **Hemispheric Comparisons**: Construct side-by-side box plots to compare hemispheric anomalies. Analyze differences in temperature patterns between hemispheres. csv file to be used: nh_temps.csv and sh_temps.csv Note: For the questions where multiple csv files are used, the 'year' column will be used to join the columns (using inner_join()) and change the names (if required) and then work on the plots. **Analysis and Interpretation**: Evaluate trends and patterns to identify regions experiencing significant anomalies. Upon analyzing the variations in different visualizations, we would be able to infer the effect of temperature anomalies on human livelihood for example in agriculture, tourism, health and global warming and discuss strategic adjustments to mitigate climate changes and work on technology advancements to improve in the future.
